context: Four boys—Fred, Juan, Marc, and Paul—and three girls—Nita, Rachel, and Trisha—will be assigned to a row of five adjacent lockers, numbered consecutively 1 through 5, arranged along a straight wall. The following conditions govern the assignment of lockers to the seven children: Each locker must be assigned to either one or two children, and each child must be assigned to exactly one locker. Each shared locker must be assigned to one girl and one boy. Juan must share a locker, but Rachel cannot share a locker. Nita's locker cannot be adjacent to Trisha's locker. Fred must be assigned to locker 3.
question: Which one of the following is a complete and accurate list of the children who must be among those assigned to shared lockers?
options: A) Fred, Juan
B) Juan, Paul
C) Juan, Marc, Paul
D) Juan, Marc, Trisha
E) Juan, Nita, Trisha
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
boys = EnumSort([Fred, Juan, Marc, Paul])
girls = EnumSort([Nita, Rachel, Trisha])
lockers = EnumSort([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
assigned = Function([boys, girls] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([b:boys, g:girls], And(assigned(b, g), assigned(g, b))) ::: each child must be assigned to exactly one locker
ForAll([b:boys, g:girls], And(assigned(b, g), assigned(g, b))) ::: each locker must be assigned to either one or two children
ForAll([b:boys, g:girls], And(assigned(b, g), assigned(g, b))) ::: each shared locker must be assigned to one girl and one boy
ForAll([b:boys, g:girls], And(assigned(b, g), assigned(g, b))) ::: Rachel cannot share a locker
ForAll([b:boys, g:girls], And(assigned(b, g), assigned(g, b))) ::: Nita's locker cannot be adjacent to Trisha's locker
ForAll([b:boys, g:girls], And(assigned(b, g), assigned(g, b))) ::: Fred must be assigned to locker 3

# Options
Question ::: ::: Which one of the following is a complete and accurate list of the children who must be among those assigned to shared lockers?
is_sat(ForAll([b:boys, g:girls], And(assigned(b, g), assigned(g, b)))) ::: (A)
is_sat(ForAll([b:boys, g:girls], And(assigned(b, g), assigned(g, b)))) ::: (B)
is_sat(ForAll([b:boys, g:girls], And(assigned(b, g), assigned(g, b)))) ::: (C)
is_sat(ForAll([b:boys, g:girls], And(assigned(b, g), assigned(g, b)))) ::: (D)
is_sat(ForAll([b:boys, g:girls], And(assigned(b, g), assigned(g, b)))) ::: (E)

B) two
C) three
D) four
E) five
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
students = EnumSort([Fernando, Ginny, Hakim, Juanita, Kevin])
performances = EnumSort([piano_recital])
perform = Function([students] -> [performances])

# Constraints
ForAll([s:students], And(1 <= perform(s) <= 5, perform(s) == perform(s + 1))) ::: each student performs one piece
And(perform(Ginny) < perform(Fernando), perform(Kevin) < perform(Hakim) < perform(Juanita)) ::: Ginny must perform earlier than Fernando. Kevin must perform earlier than Hakim and Juanita
And(perform(Hakim) == perform(Fernando) + 1, perform(Hakim) == perform(Fernando) + 2) ::: Hakim must perform either immediately before or immediately after Fernando

# Options
Question ::: How many of the students are there any one of whom could perform fourth?
is_valid(Exists([s:students], perform(s) == 4)) ::: (A)
is_valid(Exists([s:students], perform(s) == 3)) ::: (B)
is_valid(Exists([s:students], perform(s) == 2)) ::: (C)
is_valid(Exists([s:students], perform(s) == 1)) ::: (D)
is_valid(Exists([s:students], perform(s) == 5)) ::: (E)

question: Which one of the following could be the order of the presentations, from first to sixth?

teachers = EnumSort([Jiang, Kudrow, Lanning])
subjects = EnumSort([needlework, origami, pottery, stenciling, textile making, woodworking])
presentations = Function([teachers, subjects] -> [int])

# Constraints
ForAll([t:teachers, s:subjects], And(1 <= presentations(t, s), presentations(t, s) <= 6))

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following could be the order of the presentations, from first to sixth?

is_valid(Exists([s:subjects], presentations(Kudrow, s) == 2)) ::: (B)
is_valid(Exists([s:subjects], presentations(Lanning, s) == 3)) ::: (C)
is_valid(Exists([s:subjects], presentations(Kudrow, s) == 4)) ::: (D)

start_time = EnumSort([1, 1.5, 2, 2.5, 3])

ForAll([p:programs], And(start_time(p) == 1, start_time(Generations) == 1))
ForAll([p:programs], And(start_time(p) == 1.5, start_time(Roamin') == 1.5))

is_sat(ForAll([p:programs], And(start_time(p) == 1.5, start_time(Roamin') == 1.5))) ::: (B)

is_sat(ForAll([p:programs], And(start_time(p) == 3, start_time(Waterloo) == 3))) ::: (E)

trees = EnumSort([hickory, larch, maple, oak, plum, sycamore, walnut])
lots = EnumSort([1, 2, 3])
planted = Function([trees, lots] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([t:trees], And(1 <= planted(t, 1), planted(t, 1) <= 3)) ::: each tree must be planted on exactly one of three lots
And(planted(hickory, 1), planted(oak, 1)) ::: The trees planted on one lot are the hickory, the oak, and exactly one other tree
And(planted(maple, 1), Not(planted(walnut, 1))) ::: The maple is not planted on the same lot as the walnut
And(planted(larch, 2), planted(walnut, 2)) ::: Either the larch or the walnut, but not both, is planted on lot 2
And(planted(maple, 2), planted(oak, 2)) ::: Either the maple or the oak, but not both, is planted on lot 2
And(planted(plum, 3), planted(sycamore, 3)) ::: More trees are planted on lot 3 than on lot 1

# Options
Question ::: ::: Where each of the trees is planted is completely determined if which one of the following trees is planted on lot 2?
is_sat(ForAll([t:trees], planted(t, 2) == planted(t, 1))) ::: (A)
is_sat(ForAll([t:trees], planted(t, 2) == planted(t, 3))) ::: (B)
is_sat(ForAll([t:trees], planted(t, 2) == planted(t, 1) == planted(t, 3))) ::: (C)
is_sat(ForAll([t:trees], planted(t, 2) == planted(t, 1) == planted(t, 2))) ::: (D)
is_sat(ForAll([t:trees], planted(t, 2) == planted(t, 1) == planted(t, 3) == planted(t, 2))) ::: (E)
------

context: Each issue of a business newsletter has five slots, numbered 1 through 5. The policy of the newsletter requires that there are at least three features per issue, with each feature completely occupying one or more of the slots. Each feature can be one of four types—finance, industry, marketing, or technology. Any slot not containing a feature contains a graphic. The newsletters policy further requires that each issue be structured as follows: Any feature occupying more than one slot must occupy consecutively numbered slots. If an issue has any finance or technology feature, then a finance or technology feature must occupy slot 1. An issue can have at most one industry feature.
question: Which one of the following is an allowable structure for an issue of the newsletter?
options: A) slot 1: a finance feature; slot 2: an industry feature; slot 3: a second industry feature; slot 4: a graphic; slot 5: a graphic
B) slot 1: a graphic; slot 2: a technology feature; slot 3: a second technology feature; slot 4: a graphic; slot 5: a third technology feature
C) slots 1 and 2: a single industry feature; slots 3 and 4: a single marketing feature; slot 5: a finance feature
D) slot 1: a technology feature; slots 2 and 3: a single industry feature; slot 4: a finance feature; slot 5: a graphic
E) slot 1: a technology feature; slots 2 and 4: a single marketing feature; slot 3: an industry feature; slot 5: a graphic
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
features = EnumSort([finance, industry, marketing, technology])
slots = EnumSort([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
features_in_slot = Function([slots] -> [bool])
features_in_slot(slots) ::: Any feature occupying more than one slot must occupy consecutively numbered slots
features_in_slot(slots) ::: If an issue has any finance or technology feature, then a finance or technology feature must occupy slot 1
features_in_slot(slots) ::: An issue can have at most one industry feature

# Constraints
ForAll([s:slots], And(1 <= features_in_slot(s), features_in_slot(s) <= 5)) ::: each slot can contain at most one feature
ForAll([s:slots], And(1 <= features_in_slot(s), features_in_slot(s) <= 4)) ::: each slot can contain at most one feature
ForAll([s:slots], And(1 <= features_in_slot(s), features_in_slot(s) <= 3)) ::: each slot can contain at most one feature
ForAll([s:slots], And(1 <= features_in_slot(s), features_in_slot(s) <= 2)) ::: each slot can contain at most one feature
ForAll([s:slots], And(1 <= features_in_slot(s), features_in_slot(s) <= 1)) ::: each slot can contain at most one feature

# Options
Question ::: ::: Which one of the following is an allowable structure for an issue of the newsletter?
is_sat(ForAll([s:slots], And(features_in_slot(s) == 1, features_in_slot(s) == 2))) ::: (A)
is_sat(ForAll([s:slots], And(features_in_slot(s) == 1, features_in_slot(s) == 3))) ::: (B)
is_sat(ForAll([s:slots], And(features_in_slot(s) == 1, features_in_slot(s) == 4))) ::: (C)
is_sat(ForAll([s:slots], And(features_in_slot(s) == 1, features_in_slot(s) == 5))) ::: (D)
is_sat(ForAll([s:slots], And(features_in_slot(s) == 2, features_in_slot(s) == 3))) ::: (E)

Either T or U transmitted the virus to P.
question: If P is the only computer that transmitted the virus to two other computers on the network, which one of the following must be true?
options: A) S transmitted the virus to T.
B) T transmitted the virus to P.
C) Q did not transmit the virus to any other computer on the network.
D) R did not transmit the virus to any other computer on the network.
E) U did not transmit the virus to any other computer on the network.
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
computers = EnumSort([P, Q, R, S, T, U])
virus = EnumSort([P, Q, R, S, T, U])
transmitted = Function([computers, computers] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([c:computers], And(1 <= transmitted(c, c), transmitted(c, c) <= 6)) ::: no computer transmitted the virus to more than two other computers on the network
And(transmitted(S, R), transmitted(S, T)) ::: S transmitted the virus to exactly one other computer on the network
And(transmitted(R, S), transmitted(R, P)) ::: The computer that transmitted the virus to R also transmitted it to S
And(transmitted(T, Q), transmitted(T, P)) ::: Either R or T transmitted the virus to Q
And(transmitted(U, P), transmitted(U, S)) ::: Either T or U transmitted the virus to P

# Options
Question ::: If P is the only computer that transmitted the virus to two other computers on the network, which one of the following must be true?
is_sat(ForAll([c:computers], And(transmitted(c, P) == 2, transmitted(c, P) == 2))) ::: (A)
is_sat(ForAll([c:computers], And(transmitted(c, P) == 2, transmitted(c, P) == 2))) ::: (B)
is_sat(ForAll([c:computers], And(transmitted(c, P) == 2, transmitted(c, P) == 2))) ::: (C)
is_sat(ForAll([c:computers], And(transmitted(c, P) == 2, transmitted(c, P) == 2))) ::: (D)
is_sat(ForAll([c:computers], And(transmitted(c, P) == 2, transmitted(c, P) == 2))) ::: (E)
